Real Time Optimisation Through IAM Innovation
Upstream surveillance has entered a new era.
With Integrated Asset Management (IAM), teams are no longer bound by static
monitoring or delayed insights. They now operate in real time, making faster and
smarter decisions powered by live data and intelligent workflows.
This is not just a technology upgrade—it is a step change in how wells are
understood, managed, and optimised.

Overcoming Challenges at Kinabalu
IAM has been deployed across multiple fields, including recent applications at
KNNAG wells B07L, B07S, and B06T, where it helped address long standing
surveillance challenges:
•

KNNAG B07S: Slow ramp up due to water coning risk

•

KNNAG B07L: Controlled ramp up to prevent proppant production

•

Persistent metering mismatch: Discrepancy between production data and
export meter readings despite multiple recalibrations

These challenges once limited operational confidence and delayed decision making.
IAM turned that around.

How IAM Changed the Game
From static to dynamic monitoring
IAM integrated Active Well Surveillance (AWS) and Pressure Downhole Gauge (PDG) data
to enable real time well configuration, replacing manual and reactive practices.
From estimates to validated rates
Using the Vertical Lift Performance (VLP) method, IAM resolved mismatches between
production and export readings, ensuring accuracy and reliability.
From single point to multipoint validation
The Multiphase Flow Meter (MPFM) Validation Workflow compared wellhead gas meter data
with Flowing Tubing Head Pressure (FTHP) and PDG pressure readings, improving
confidence in bean up decisions.
From delayed response to early action
Live validation during operations helped detect water coning earlier, reducing risks and
capturing additional gains.

IAM-Driven Enhancements
•

Real time well rate estimation using AWS, and PDG enabled accurate export meter
matching, unlocking 3 MMSCFD from KNNAG B06T

•

MPFM validation workflow identified KNNAG B07S for further bean up, with live
Wellhead Gas Meter (WGM) monitoring during execution

•

Ramp up strategies for B07S and B07L were optimised to mitigate water
coning and proppant production risks, improving zone contribution

The results speak for themselves:
•

23 MMSCFD in additional gas production

•

1 KBOED from the most productive condensate line up identified through IAM

•

Greater precision and confidence in surveillance and decision making

IAM has proven to be more than a modelling tool. It is a strategic enabler that drives
operational excellence.

What's Next
The next step is clear: scaling IAM across all PCSB assets.
This will transform surveillance into a proactive, predictive, and performance driven
discipline, setting a new benchmark for upstream operations.
The future of optimisation is here.
And it is happening in real time.

Why Fit-for-Purpose Standard and Strategic
Contracting Matter More Than Ever
The KNNAG Phase 3 Drilling Campaign

This campaign redefined upstream execution—delivering more wells, faster timelines, and smarter
solutions through bold innovation and strategic flexibility. With a Systemic Shifts mindset and the
right behaviors at the core, here's how the team made it happen.
Section 1: Breaking the Mold – Standards Reimagined
Key Change:
Embraced a more risk tolerant mindset by ensuring fit-for-purpose standards implementation,
which enabled innovative, risk-assessed solutions.
Highlights:
•Conducted collaborative risk assessments for collision management, enabling safe and
informed decision-making.
•

Granted technical dispensation to allow a single barrier, despite intersecting a safety
valve in a neighboring high-pressure well.

•Accepted calculated risks in well control equipment, supported by the availability of manual
intervention.
•Raised six Technical Deviations:
•

Two related to collision management for plug setting (PTS)

•

Three related to well control philosophy (PTS)

•

One Management of Change (MOC) to realise operational optimisation

•

Impact:
Cost savings of MYR 12.3 million

opportunity for conductor cleanout

Section 2: Smarter Design – Optimization Post-Sanction
Key Change:
Design evolved based on actual field conditions rather than pre-sanction assumptions.
Highlights:
•Conducted extensive rig-platform clash checks, eliminating the need for major
modifications to accommodate rig entry.
•Revised completion design from tie-back to cemented monobore, leveraging proven success
from previous projects to enhance performance.
•Applied effective mud design and wellbore strengthening to manage high pore pressure
contrast between depleted and virgin zones, enabling safe high overbalance drilling with no
losses.

•Deployed downhole vibration tools and high-performance drilling bits to reduce friction
and improve drilling efficiency, minimizing the need for multiple trips and successfully reaching
section TD.
•Implemented a focused logistics plan utilizing only two supply vessels to manage restricted
deck load caused by soft shallow formations, ensuring safe and timely drilling operations
Impact:
Cost savings of MYR 34.5 million

Section 3: Contracting Reinvented – Performance-Driven Agreements
Key Change:
Shift from traditional contracts to integrated, performance-based models, specifically the
Integrated Rig, Drilling, and Completion Contract (iRDC).
Highlights:
•Introduced Defined Scope with Risk-Free Pricing, where contractors quote a unit rate based
on an agreed and ring-fenced scope, minimizing pricing uncertainty.
•Implemented a Bonus-Malus Performance Incentive System to reward contractors for
outperforming pledged timelines and penalize delays.
•Enforced Non-Productive Time (NPT) Accountability, where any NPT reduces the
contractor's pre-committed time allowance, and excess duration triggers malus rates or
discounts.
•Enabled Technology Deployment Flexibility, allowing contractors to utilize any available
service or technology to improve well delivery time and earn performance bonuses.
Impact:
Cost savings of MYR 49.6 million.

And the results speak for themselves across safety, budget, timeline, and scope.

"Setting the Standard for Future Campaigns"
Kinabalu Phase 3 proved that with the right mindset and tools, technical limits can be challenged and surpassed—
leaving a legacy of efficiency, safety, and performance.

examples.title: The Future Is Here — EPIC 2.0: Turning Data Chaos into Exploration Clarity
examples.useCase: Best for technology platform launches and major infrastructure projects
examples.writeup:
For Internal Use - For Internal Distribution Only

The Future Is Here —
EPIC 2.0
Turning Data Chaos into Exploration Clarity
Imagine this: You're deep into a challenging exploration project. The data is
massive, the geology is complex, and deadlines are tight. What if you had a digital
powerhouse that could process seismic data, simulate reservoirs, and help you
make smarter decisions—all at lightning speed?
That's what EPIC 2.0 brings to PETRONAS Upstream and Petroleum Arrangement
Contractors (PACs) in Malaysia. And as of 25 September 2025, it's officially live.

What Is EPIC 2.0
EPIC 2.0 stands for Enterprise Platform for Integrated Computing. It is our nextgeneration High Performance Computing (HPC) and Artificial Intelligence (AI)
platform, built to handle the scale and complexity of modern upstream
challenges—from seismic imaging to reservoir modelling—with speed, precision,
and intelligence.
Key Capabilities
•

Sharper subsurface imaging
Supports Elastic Full Waveform Inversion (EFWI), using pressure and shear
wavefields to deliver high-resolution subsurface models in complex
geological settings.

•

Smart, integrated Earth models
Combines static and dynamic reservoir data with AI-driven interpretation to
improve decision-making and streamline workflows. Includes enhanced
model resolution, faster simulation runtimes, and scalable support for
history matching and predictive modelling.

•

Accelerated processing
Combines large-scale parallel computing, GPU acceleration, and optimised
input/output strategies to reduce turnaround time from days to hours.

•

Optimised for internal innovation
Runs PETRONAS proprietary algorithms at scale, turning internal technology
into a competitive edge.

Go-Live Milestone

EPIC 2.0 went live on 25 September 2025, supporting high-priority projects
in Suriname, Turkmenistan, PM419, and SB409. This milestone was delivered
through collaboration between Product Delivery Upstream, Upstream Technology
Data and Innovation, and Group Procurement PT and HSSE.
A full rollout is planned by mid-December 2025, with EPIC 2.0 ready to meet
seismic imaging demand projected to reach 85,000 km² between 2025 and 2028.
It also complements EPIC 1.0, which is currently operating at 80 to 90 percent
utilization. By adding parallel processing capabilities, EPIC 2.0 ensures sustained
performance for increasingly complex imaging operations.

Strategic Technology Partnerships Powering Sustainability
EPIC 2.0 is powered by DUG's world-class HPC platform and its advanced MultiParameter Full Waveform Inversion seismic technologies. This foundation brings
cutting-edge seismic processing capabilities and sustainability features to
PETRONAS.
DUG's expertise enhances imaging precision and turnaround speed for critical
exploration zones, while supporting PETRONAS internal innovation.
EPIC 2.0 is also engineered for efficiency and environmental responsibility.
•

Immersion cooling system
Servers are submerged in thermally conductive dielectric fluid, enabling
direct-to-chip heat removal. This method improves heat transfer, reduces
cooling energy use by up to 90 percent, and enhances hardware reliability.

•

PETRONAS-developed thermal fluids
These fluids reduce overall power consumption by up to 50 percent and are
being progressively adopted to optimise performance and sustainability.

A Platform for the Future
EPIC 2.0 is more than a technology upgrade—it's a shift in how we work.
•

Faster simulations - quicker decisions

•

Integrated models - better collaboration

•

AI-powered workflows - smarter outcomes

•

Scalable HPC infrastructure - supports growing complexity

•

EFWI - deeper subsurface insight

•

DUG partnership - global seismic expertise

Next time you see a breakthrough in imaging, a faster turnaround, or smoother
collaboration, know that it is powered behind the scenes by a platform built for
scale, speed, and smarter decisions.
EPIC 2.0 is here. Let's put it to work.

examples.title: Decarbonisation at Tiong A: Simple Steps, Big Impact
examples.useCase: Best for sustainability stories with environmental impact and operational improvements
examples.writeup:
For Internal Use - For Internal Distribution Only

Decarbonisation at Tiong A: Simple Steps, Big Impact
By PCSB-PMA in collaboration with Carbon Management Division (CMD)

What if a single valve could help us get closer to our 2030 climate goals? At Tiong A, a simple
question led to a powerful answer showing that small, practical steps can deliver big wins for
both the environment and our business.

A Persistent Challenge
Tiong A, part of the Peninsular Malaysia Asset (PMA) under PETRONAS Carigali Sdn. Bhd.
(PCSB), recently underwent a major brownfield modification through the Integrated Bekok Oil
(IBO) project. The goal was clear: reduce flaring and support PETRONAS Upstream's
decarbonisation journey.
However, following the commissioning of the IBO project in October 2024, the team
encountered an unexpected challenge that put their resolve and the project's objectives to the
test. Despite the upgrades and sufficient gas handling capacity, Tiong A's flaring levels
remained persistently elevated, averaging up to 11 MMscf/d. This translated to 0.26 million
tCO₂e per year, threatening Upstream's 2030 target to cap absolute GHG emissions at 17.25
million tCO₂e.

Teamwork and Technology in Action
Determined to tackle the issue, a multidisciplinary taskforce sprang into action. Their mission
was clear: to identify and eliminate non-routine flaring sources using solutions that were both
cost-effective and practical.
The team's strategy blended data-driven analysis with hands-on fieldwork:
• Acoustic emission testing allowed the team to "listen" for hidden leaks across all
high-pressure flare sources, revealing issues that might otherwise go undetected.
•
P&ID reviews and thorough on-site valve inspections helped zero in on the most likely
trouble spots.
• Through this rigorous investigation, the team pinpointed passing manual bypass and
control valves specifically PCV-135D and PCV-120A as the main contributors to
excessive flaring during normal operations.

Short-term solution: During a one-day ESD shutdown in March 2025, the team temporarily
blinded the PCV-135D manual bypass valve and recalibrated critical control valves. All actions
were risk-assessed and approved to ensure operational safety.
Long-term solution: In June 2025, during a scheduled maintenance shutdown (MSD), the
team replaced the passing manual bypass valve, upgraded the PCV-135D trim, and adjusted
the PCV-120A stem, permanently addressing the root causes.

Results That Matter
The impact of these targeted interventions was both immediate and far-reaching.

Phase 1 saw flaring rates at Tiong A plummet from 11 MMscf/d to just 4 MMscf/d after the
initial blinding of the bypass valve and recalibration of controls. This single step alone
translated into a reduction of 0.21 million tCO₂e per year, preventing an estimated RM32.19
million in annual hydrocarbon losses that would have otherwise gone up in smoke.
Building on this momentum, Phase 2 delivered even greater results. Permanent rectification
during the June 2025 maintenance shutdown further reduced flaring to an impressive 1.5
MMscf/d, cutting an additional 0.073 million tCO₂e and saving another RM11.5 million per
year.
These achievements mean that Tiong A now consistently operates below its daily flaring limit
of 1.7 MMscf/d, not only meeting but exceeding operational KPIs. More importantly, this
success story directly supports Upstream's 2030 target to cap absolute GHG emissions at
17.25 million tCO₂e.
A Blueprint for the Future
This initiative is more than a technical fix. It's a model for how Upstream can deliver on
"Systemic Shift #8: Operate it Right," maximising production while minimising carbon intensity.
It proves that operational efficiency and sustainability go hand-in-hand, and that every staff
member has a role to play in decarbonisation.
